qas.question: What is one way that videoconferencing is useful?
What areas benefit especially from videoconferencing?
In what US state did a rural area use videoconferencing to help reduce the number of transfers of sick infants to hospitals?
How far away was the hospital from this rural area?
How much money did videoconferencing help this rural area save?
What areas make contacting nurses more streamlined?
How much did it cost to contact a doctor in rural Ohio?
Where did a medical center use transmission of medical images to cut costs?
How far away was the doctor from the rural area in Ohio?
What allows medical centers to discuss cases across large distances?

context: Videoconferencing is a highly useful technology for <a0_0>real-time telemedicine<a0_0/> and telenursing applications, such as diagnosis, consulting, transmission of medical images, etc... With <b9_0>videoconferencing<b9_0/>, patients may contact nurses and physicians in emergency or routine situations; physicians and other paramedical professionals can discuss cases across large distances. <a1_0><b5_0>Rural<a1_0/> areas<b5_0/> can use this technology for diagnostic purposes, thus saving lives and making more efficient use of health care money. For example, a rural medical center in <a2_0><b7_0>Ohio<b7_0/><a2_0/>, United States, used videoconferencing to successfully cut the number of transfers of sick infants to a hospital <a3_0><b8_0>70 miles<a3_0/> (110 km) away<b8_0/>. This had previously cost nearly <a4_0><b6_0>$10,000<b6_0/> per transfer<a4_0/>.
